Award.AwardTitle: New Problems in Mean Field Control Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mean field games were introduced in 2006, independently by Lasry-Lions and Huang-Caines-Malham√©. Their idea was to adapt the mean field approach from physics and mechanics to social sciences. The mean field approach allows the description of the macroscopic behavior of fluids and gases without considering the motion of the individual particles. One can consider a representative particle whose dynamics is influenced by a mean field term that represents an averaging effect coming from all other particles. In the social sciences, particles are replaced with agents. For example, an agent can be a car when modeling traffic on highways. An important difference from physics is that the agents are decision makers and the dynamics correspond to decisions. This proposal develops control methods for these mean field models, called Mean Field Control Theory. Results will be applied to dynamic networks and provide insight for applications such as economic theory.

A basic problem in mean field control theory is to solve a system of Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman and Fokker Planck (HJB-FP) equations. The Master Equation, introduced by Lions, allows one to encapsulate the system of HJB-FP equations in a single equation by driving a decoupling argument. A serious difficulty is the fact that one needs to work with functions of probability measures. Lions introduced the idea that one could write the Master Equation using for the space of arguments the Hilbert space of square integrable random variables. This leads to new control problems in this particular Hilbert space, which is the first objective of the research. The second objective is to study specific problems in mean field control theory, motivated by economics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mean field control theory is a branch of mathematics that allows us to model optimal strategic crowd behavior. The purpose of this project was to make fundamental advances in the theory to allow a greater scope of applications. We had two major directions. First, we studied the so-called "master equation," which is a new type of differential equation that tells us the optimal strategy given any initial crowd distribution. Our goal in this direction was to develop new mathematical theory related to the control of infinite dimensional systems. Second, we studied particular examples that come from economics. Specifically, our analysis of differential equations gives a mathematical foundation for answering questions about global markets in oil and other exhaustible resources.

Our main technical contributions have been published in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings, totalling 18 articles. These contributions include a new approach to the master equation, in which we represent crowd distributions by random variables, then apply the methods of optimal control on Hilbert spaces (this idea was suggested by P.-L. Lions, one of the fathers of mean field type control). We wrote our main result in a paper currently under review. In our other papers we have analyzed systems of equations and their applications. Our approach uses classical methods from stochastic optimal control, partial differential equations, and infinite dimensional analysis. These results are well-respected in the mathematical community, and we have presented them at 17 invited lectures at conferences and seminars.

Students played in a vital role in this research project. One student at UT Dallas, Joohyun Kim, completed his PHD under the direction of the PI and continues to do research related to mean field type control. At Baylor, the co-PI directed an undergraduate honors thesis by Marcus Laurel, who solved a problem related to economic applications. Marcus is now a PHD student.

The end result of this project is a new set of open problems and directions for the mathematical community. Most urgent is the question of so-called "common noise," which means randomness affecting all observers at once. Economists are interested in this because of so-called "aggregate shocks" in the market. To address this question, we will need to develop a better understanding of stochastic partial differential equations. This is a topic of our continuing research.
